definitions: move or pass from one state, place, or condition to another
cause something to change smoothly from one state to another
examples: The company will transition to renewable energy sources next year
Many students struggle to transition from high school to college
The director transitioned seamlessly between the dramatic scenes
We need to transition these systems gradually over several months

definitions: express the meaning of words or text in another language
express or convert something in different terms or form
move something from one place or position to another
examples: She can translate ancient Greek texts into modern English
The software automatically translates websites into multiple languages
How do we translate these abstract concepts into practical actions?
His research translates complex theories into everyday language
The designer translated the logo across the page layout
These mechanisms translate rotational motion into linear movement

definitions: send or broadcast electronic signals, messages, or data from one place to another
pass on a disease or infection to another person or organism
communicate or pass on information, knowledge, or ideas to others
examples: The satellite transmits data back to Earth every hour
Radio towers transmit signals across vast distances
Mosquitoes can transmit malaria to humans through their bites
The virus transmits easily between people in crowded spaces
Teachers transmit knowledge and values to their students daily
Cultural traditions transmit wisdom from generation to generation

definitions: move a plant from one place and replant it in another location
transfer an organ or tissue from one body to another medically
move someone or something to a different place or environment permanently
examples: We transplanted the rose bushes to the sunny side of the garden
Spring is the best time to transplant young seedlings outdoors
The surgeon successfully transplanted a kidney from the donor
Doctors can now transplant hearts, lungs, and livers routinely
The family transplanted themselves from the city to rural Vermont
The company transplanted its entire operation to a new facility

definitions: carry or move people or goods from one place to another by vehicle
cause someone to feel strong emotion or be carried away imaginatively
send convicted criminals to a penal colony as historical punishment
examples: Trucks transport fresh produce from farms to markets daily
The airline transports millions of passengers around the world annually
The beautiful music transported her to another time and place
His storytelling transported the audience to ancient Rome
Britain transported convicts to Australia in the eighteenth century
Criminals were transported to penal colonies for serious offenses

definitions: cause two or more things to change places or positions with each other
write or play music in a different key from the original
transfer or rewrite something into a different form or medium
examples: The editor accidentally transposed two paragraphs in the document
If you transpose these numbers, you'll get the wrong answer
Can you transpose this song from C major to G major?
The pianist transposed the piece down two semitones
She transposed her novel into a screenplay for television
The data was transposed from rows into columns

definitions: catch an animal or person using a device or enclosure
prevent someone from escaping or confine them in an unpleasant situation
collect or retain substances, heat, or particles in a particular place
examples: Hunters trap rabbits using snares in the forest
The spider trapped the fly in its intricate web
The avalanche trapped several skiers on the mountain overnight
Don't let yourself get trapped in a dead-end job
These filters trap dust particles before they enter the engine
Greenhouse gases trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere

definitions: damage, destroy, or vandalize something severely and deliberately
criticize someone or something in a harsh and unfair manner
throw away or discard something as worthless garbage or waste
examples: Vandals trashed the abandoned building over the weekend
The rock stars trashed their hotel room after the concert
Critics completely trashed the new movie despite its popularity
She trashed her ex-boyfriend's reputation on social media
Please trash those old magazines when you're done reading
The company trashed thousands of defective products

definitions: go from one place to another, typically over a considerable distance
move or progress through space, time, or a medium
spread or be transmitted through an area or group rapidly
examples: She travels to Europe twice a year for business
We traveled across the country by train last summer
Light travels faster than sound through the atmosphere
The baseball traveled over four hundred feet
News travels fast in small communities these days
The virus can travel through air droplets between people

definitions: travel or move across, through, or over an area or terrain
move back and forth or sideways across something
examine, consider, or discuss a subject comprehensively and systematically
examples: The expedition will traverse the entire mountain range
Hikers traverse dangerous terrain to reach the summit
The climber carefully traversed along the narrow ledge
The crane traverses horizontally across the construction site
The report traverses all aspects of climate change policy
Her research traverses multiple academic disciplines

definitions: represent something in a false, absurd, or distorted way that mocks it
make something into a grotesque or debased imitation or version
examples: The movie travesties historical events for cheap entertainment
The comedian travestied the politician's speech brilliantly
The new policy travesties everything we've worked to achieve
Don't travesty my words to suit your argument

definitions: catch fish by dragging a large net through the water behind a boat
search through a large amount of information or area looking for something
examples: Fishing boats trawl these waters for cod and haddock
They trawled the ocean floor with massive nets
Police trawled through hours of security footage for clues
Researchers trawled the archives looking for historical documents

definitions: walk in a specified way, especially carefully or with caution
walk on or along a surface, path, or area
press or crush something with one's feet while walking
examples: She treads carefully through the minefield of office politics
Tread softly so you don't wake the sleeping baby
Thousands of tourists tread this ancient path every year
The actors tread the boards of Broadway nightly
Don't tread on the newly planted grass seedlings
The grapes are still trodden by foot in traditional wineries

definitions: value, appreciate, or regard someone or something as precious and important
keep or store something carefully because it is valuable or special
examples: She treasures the memories of her childhood summers
Parents treasure every moment with their children
He treasures that old watch his grandfather gave him
The museum treasures these rare artifacts in climate-controlled rooms

definitions: behave toward or deal with someone in a particular way
give medical care or attention to a patient or condition
provide someone with food, entertainment, or gifts as a special pleasure
apply a process or substance to something to protect or preserve it
examples: She always treats her employees with respect and fairness
The school treats bullying as a serious disciplinary matter
The doctor treats patients with chronic pain conditions
This medication treats high blood pressure effectively
Let me treat you to dinner for your birthday
The company treats its staff to an annual holiday party
The wood is treated with chemicals to prevent rot
They treat the water before it enters the supply system

definitions: make or become three times as large, numerous, or intense
sing or play the highest part in musical harmony
examples: Housing prices have trebled in the last decade
The company trebled its profits through international expansion
The young boy trebles beautifully in the church choir
She trebled the high notes with perfect clarity

definitions: force a person or animal to take refuge in a tree
put someone in a difficult position with no escape options
examples: The hunting dogs treed the raccoon within minutes
The bear was treed by the aggressive wolves
The reporter's questions completely treed the politician
Don't let them tree you into making hasty decisions

definitions: make a long, difficult journey, especially on foot through rough terrain
migrate or journey with one's belongings, especially historically
examples: We trekked through the jungle for three exhausting days
Thousands trek to base camp every climbing season
The pioneers trekked westward in covered wagons
Nomadic tribes trek across the desert following water sources

definitions: shake involuntarily from fear, excitement, cold, or weakness
move or vibrate with slight, rapid movements
be in a state of extreme fear or anxiety about something
examples: Her hands trembled as she opened the envelope
The old man trembled from the bitter cold
The leaves trembled gently in the evening breeze
The bridge trembled under the weight of heavy traffic
She trembled at the thought of speaking publicly
Investors tremble whenever the market becomes volatile

definitions: undergo or cause slight shaking or trembling movements
produce small, irregular vibratory movements
examples: His voice tremored with emotion during the speech
The ground tremored from the distant explosion
The needle tremored as it recorded seismic activity
Her lips tremored as she tried not to cry

definitions: dig a long, narrow ditch or excavation in the ground
fortify a position by digging defensive trenches around it
examples: Workers trenched the field to install drainage pipes
They trenched along the property line for the fence
Soldiers trenched their positions during the long siege
The army trenched the hillside for defensive purposes

definitions: show a general tendency in a particular direction over time
become popular or fashionable, especially on social media
examples: Unemployment rates are trending downward this quarter
Stock prices trend higher during economic recovery
That hashtag is trending worldwide on Twitter today
Vintage fashion is trending among young consumers

definitions: deceive or outwit someone through cunning or skillful means
use skill or dexterity to manipulate something into a desired position
examples: The con artist tricked elderly victims out of their savings
Don't let him trick you into signing that contract
The goalkeeper tricked the ball around the defender
She tricked the mechanism into working despite the damage

definitions: flow in a small, gentle stream or in drops
come, go, or happen slowly and gradually in small numbers
examples: Water trickled down the rock face into the pool
Blood trickled from the small cut on his finger
Customers trickled into the store throughout the morning
Information about the scandal trickled out over several weeks

definitions: treat someone or something without seriousness or respect
waste time or act frivolously with unimportant matters
examples: Don't trifle with her emotions like that
He's not someone you should trifle with lightly
Stop trifling and focus on your important work
She trifled away the afternoon reading gossip magazines

definitions: cause a device or mechanism to function or activate
cause an emotional reaction or response in someone
cause an event or process to happen or begin
examples: Pull the lever to trigger the emergency alarm
The sensor triggers the lights when someone enters
Loud noises can trigger anxiety in some people
That song always triggers memories of my childhood
The announcement triggered a wave of protests nationwide
Rising temperatures trigger the migration of certain birds

definitions: produce a quavering or vibratory sound, especially in singing
make a warbling sound like that of certain birds
examples: The opera singer trilled the high notes magnificently
She trilled with joy when she heard the news
Birds trilled in the trees at dawn
The flute trilled a cheerful melody

definitions: make something neat by cutting away irregular or unwanted parts
decorate something by adding ornamental edges or borders
adjust the balance of a ship or aircraft by arranging cargo
examples: The barber trimmed his beard to perfection
She trims the hedges every month during summer
They trimmed the Christmas tree with lights and ornaments
The dress was trimmed with delicate lace
The crew trimmed the sails to catch the wind
Pilots trim the aircraft for level flight

definitions: catch one's foot and stumble or fall
walk, run, or dance with quick light steps
activate a mechanism or switch, especially accidentally
experience hallucinations from psychedelic drugs
examples: She tripped over the uneven pavement and scraped her knee
Be careful not to trip on that loose carpet
The children tripped happily across the meadow
Dancers tripped lightly across the stage
He accidentally tripped the fire alarm during renovation
The overload tripped the circuit breaker
Some people claim to trip for hours on mushrooms
He was tripping and seeing vivid colors everywhere

definitions: make or become three times as much or as many
hit a ball allowing the batter to reach third base
examples: The company tripled its revenue in just two years
Food prices have tripled since the crisis began
The batter tripled to deep center field
She tripled in the bottom of the ninth inning

definitions: achieve a great victory or success after difficulty or conflict
feel or express great joy or satisfaction about a victory
examples: The team triumphed against all odds in the championship
She triumphed over cancer after years of treatment
The winners triumphed openly, celebrating their hard-earned victory
He couldn't help but triumph when his predictions proved correct

definitions: fish by trailing a baited line behind a slowly moving boat
deliberately post inflammatory messages online to provoke others
search through or patrol an area looking for something
examples: They trolled for salmon in the deep waters
Fishermen troll these waters during the summer months
Don't feed the people who troll in comment sections
He trolls political forums just to start arguments
Security guards troll the parking lot every hour
She trolled through vintage shops looking for treasures

definitions: move together in a group or in large numbers
march or walk in an organized military formation
examples: The children trooped into the classroom after recess
Tourists troop through the museum every summer day
Soldiers trooped past the reviewing stand in perfect order
The regiment trooped the colors during the ceremony

definitions: move at a pace faster than walking but slower than running
bring out or present something in a casual or routine way
examples: The horse trotted around the paddock for exercise
She trotted alongside her jogging partner
He always trots out the same old excuses
The company trots out new products every season

definitions: cause distress, worry, or inconvenience to someone
disturb or bother someone with requests or concerns
make the effort to do something despite difficulty
examples: Financial problems have troubled the family for years
His persistent cough troubles me greatly
Sorry to trouble you, but could you help me?
Don't trouble the neighbors with loud music
She didn't trouble to hide her disappointment
Why trouble yourself with such minor details?

definitions: convey or transport goods or materials by truck
have dealings or association with someone or something
examples: The company trucks fresh produce across the country daily
They trucked the equipment to the construction site
I don't truck with dishonest people
She refuses to truck with corporate politics

definitions: bring something into the exact shape, alignment, or position required
make something straight, level, or properly positioned
examples: The carpenter trued the door frame with his level
You need to true the wheel before riding
The mechanic trued the bent axle carefully
True the blade to ensure a clean cut

definitions: surpass or beat someone or something by doing better
play a trump card in a card game to win
invent false accusations or charges against someone
examples: Quality trumps quantity in luxury goods markets
Her experience trumped all other candidates' qualifications
She trumped his ace with the king of hearts
You can't trump in this round of the game
The authorities trumped up charges to silence dissidents
They tried to trump up evidence against him

definitions: play music on a trumpet instrument
proclaim or announce something widely and loudly
make the characteristic loud cry of an elephant
examples: He trumpeted jazz melodies at the club every Friday
The band trumpeted the national anthem beautifully
The company trumpeted its success in every press release
Politicians trumpet their achievements before elections
The elephant trumpeted loudly to warn the herd
Zoo elephants often trumpet when excited

definitions: shorten something by cutting off the top, end, or a part
reduce the length or duration of something abruptly
examples: The editor truncated the article to fit the space
They truncated the pyramid at the construction site
Budget cuts truncated the research project prematurely
The system automatically truncates file names over thirty characters

definitions: believe in the reliability, truth, or ability of someone or something
have confidence or faith in someone or something
allow someone to have or use something in confidence
examples: She trusts her doctor's medical advice completely
Can we trust these statistics to be accurate?
I trust you'll make the right decision
Never trust strangers with personal information
They trusted him with the company's financial records
She trusts her assistant to handle important calls

definitions: make an attempt or effort to do or accomplish something
test something to assess its suitability or effectiveness
subject someone to trial in a court of law
make severe demands on someone's patience or endurance
examples: She tried to solve the complex equation herself
Try turning it off and on again
You should try this new restaurant downtown
Try the shoes on before you buy them
The court will try the defendant next month
They tried him for embezzlement and fraud
These constant delays really try my patience
Don't try me with your excuses today

definitions: shape or form something into a tube or cylinder
travel on the London Underground railway system
examples: The metal was tubed to create the exhaust pipe
They tubed the paper into a cylindrical shape
We tubed to central London every morning
It's faster to tube than to drive there

definitions: push, fold, or arrange something into a small neat space
put someone, especially a child, comfortably in bed
eat food heartily or with enthusiasm
examples: She tucked her shirt into her skirt neatly
Tuck the edges under before you sew
Mother tucked the children into bed every night
He tucked the baby under a warm blanket
The boys tucked into their dinner hungrily
We tucked into the feast with great enthusiasm

definitions: make someone extremely tired or exhausted through exertion
examples: The long hike completely tuckered out the children
Don't tucker yourself out before the main event
All that dancing has tuckered me out
The puppies were tuckered after playing all afternoon

definitions: pull something hard or suddenly with force
tow a ship or boat using a tugboat
examples: The child tugged at her mother's sleeve persistently
He tugged the rope until it finally came loose
The tugboat tugged the cargo ship into port
They tugged the disabled yacht to safety

definitions: fall suddenly, clumsily, or headlong
decrease rapidly in amount or value
understand or become aware of something suddenly
examples: The toddler tumbled down the stairs accidentally
Rocks tumbled from the cliff during the earthquake
Stock prices tumbled after the announcement
Sales have tumbled by fifty percent this quarter
She finally tumbled to what he was planning
It took me ages to tumble to their scheme

definitions: adjust a musical instrument to the correct or uniform pitch
adjust a radio or television to receive a particular station
bring into harmony or make responsive to something
examples: The guitarist tuned her instrument before the performance
The piano needs to be tuned every six months
Tune the radio to 94.5 FM for classical music
She tuned in to watch the evening news
You need to tune your message to your audience
The company tuned its strategy to market demands

definitions: dig or bore a passage underground or through something
move or proceed through a tunnel or confined space
examples: Workers tunneled through the mountain for the new railway
Prisoners tunneled under the wall to escape
The train tunneled through the Alps
Moles tunnel through gardens searching for food

definitions: cover an area of ground with turf or grass
force someone to leave a place or position unceremoniously
examples: They turfed the entire football field last spring
We need to turf this bare patch in the garden
Security turfed him out of the club for fighting
She was turfed from her position after the scandal
